questions.question: What is Flutter?
questions.answer: Flutter is an open-source UI framework by Google used to build natively compiled applications for mobile, web, and desktop from a single codebase.

questions.question: What programming language does Flutter use?
questions.answer: Flutter uses Dart, a language optimized for UI development with JIT and AOT compilation.

questions.question: What is hot reload in Flutter?
questions.answer: Hot reload allows developers to instantly see code changes without restarting the app or losing state.

questions.question: What is the Flutter engine?
questions.answer: The Flutter engine is written in C++ and provides rendering, text layout, and platform interaction.

questions.question: Is Flutter native?
questions.answer: Flutter is not native but compiles to native ARM code and uses platform channels to access native APIs.

questions.question: What platforms does Flutter support?
questions.answer: Flutter supports Android, iOS, Web, Windows, macOS, and Linux.

questions.question: What is pubspec.yaml?
questions.answer: pubspec.yaml manages dependencies, assets, fonts, and project metadata.

questions.question: What is MaterialApp?
questions.answer: MaterialApp is a widget that sets up material design, routing, themes, and localization.

questions.question: What is Cupertino in Flutter?
questions.answer: Cupertino widgets provide iOS-style UI components.

questions.question: What is the widget tree?
questions.answer: The widget tree represents the hierarchical structure of widgets in a Flutter app.

topics.title: Widgets & UI
topics.description: Widgets, layouts, and UI building in Flutter

questions.question: What is a widget?
questions.answer: A widget is the basic building block of the Flutter UI.

questions.question: Difference between StatelessWidget and StatefulWidget?
questions.answer: StatelessWidget is immutable, while StatefulWidget can rebuild when its state changes.

questions.question: What is BuildContext?
questions.answer: BuildContext provides the location of a widget in the widget tree.

questions.question: What does setState do?
questions.answer: setState notifies Flutter that the widget state has changed and needs rebuilding.

questions.question: What are keys in Flutter?
questions.answer: Keys help Flutter preserve widget state when widgets move in the tree.

questions.question: What is MediaQuery?
questions.answer: MediaQuery provides screen size, orientation, and device pixel ratio.

questions.question: What is LayoutBuilder?
questions.answer: LayoutBuilder builds widgets based on parent constraints.

questions.question: What is SafeArea?
questions.answer: SafeArea prevents UI from overlapping system UI like notches.

questions.question: What is Expanded widget?
questions.answer: Expanded makes a child of Row or Column fill available space.

questions.question: What is Flexible widget?
questions.answer: Flexible controls how a child flexes inside a Row or Column.

questions.question: What is state in Flutter?
questions.answer: State represents data that can change over time and affect UI.

questions.question: What is setState used for?
questions.answer: It is used to update local widget state.

questions.question: What is BLoC?
questions.answer: BLoC separates business logic from UI using streams of events and states.

questions.question: Difference between Provider and BLoC?
questions.answer: Provider is simpler, BLoC enforces strict separation and scalability.

questions.question: What is Cubit?
questions.answer: Cubit is a simplified version of BLoC with fewer abstractions.

questions.question: What is Riverpod?
questions.answer: Riverpod is a reactive caching and dependency injection framework.

questions.question: Why is state management important?
questions.answer: It keeps UI predictable, scalable, and testable.

questions.question: What is immutable state?
questions.answer: Immutable state cannot be modified after creation.

questions.question: What is global state?
questions.answer: State shared across multiple widgets or screens.

questions.question: What is local state?
questions.answer: State that is confined to a single widget.

questions.question: What is Navigator?
questions.answer: Navigator manages a stack of routes.

questions.question: What is a route?
questions.answer: A route represents a screen or page.

questions.question: Difference between push and pushReplacement?
questions.answer: push adds a route, pushReplacement replaces the current route.

questions.question: What is go_router?
questions.answer: go_router is a declarative routing package for Flutter.

questions.question: What is named routing?
questions.answer: Navigation using route names instead of widgets.

questions.question: What is deep linking?
questions.answer: Deep linking opens a specific screen via a URL.

questions.question: What is route guard?
questions.answer: Restricts navigation based on conditions like auth.

questions.question: What is popUntil?
questions.answer: Pops routes until a condition is met.

questions.question: What is WillPopScope?
questions.answer: Intercepts back navigation.

questions.question: What is nested navigation?
questions.answer: Navigation inside a sub-tree.

topics.title: Async Programming
topics.description: Asynchronous programming and concurrency in Flutter

questions.question: What is asynchronous programming?
questions.answer: Asynchronous programming allows tasks to run without blocking the main thread.

questions.question: What is Future in Dart?
questions.answer: A Future represents a value that will be available at a later time.

questions.question: What is async and await?
questions.answer: async and await simplify working with Futures by writing asynchronous code in a synchronous style.

questions.question: What is Stream?
questions.answer: A Stream provides a sequence of asynchronous events over time.

questions.question: Difference between Future and Stream?
questions.answer: Future emits a single value, Stream emits multiple values.

questions.question: What is Isolate?
questions.answer: An Isolate runs code in a separate memory space for parallel execution.

questions.question: What is compute() in Flutter?
questions.answer: compute() runs heavy tasks in a background isolate.

questions.question: What is event loop?
questions.answer: The event loop schedules and executes asynchronous tasks.

questions.question: What is microtask queue?
questions.answer: Microtasks are executed before the event queue.

questions.question: How do you handle errors in async code?
questions.answer: Using try-catch blocks or Future.catchError.

topics.title: Architecture & Clean Code
topics.description: App architecture, design patterns, and clean code principles

questions.question: What is Clean Architecture?
questions.answer: Clean Architecture separates concerns into layers for scalability and testability.

questions.question: What are layers in Clean Architecture?
questions.answer: Presentation, Domain, and Data layers.

questions.question: What is separation of concerns?
questions.answer: Each part of the app handles a specific responsibility.

questions.question: What is SOLID principle?
questions.answer: A set of design principles for maintainable and scalable code.

questions.question: What is dependency injection?
questions.answer: Providing dependencies externally rather than creating them internally.

questions.question: What is repository pattern?
questions.answer: Repository abstracts data sources from business logic.

questions.question: What is MVVM?
questions.answer: Model-View-ViewModel separates UI and business logic.

questions.question: Why avoid business logic in UI?
questions.answer: It improves testability and maintainability.

questions.question: What is feature-based architecture?
questions.answer: Organizing code by feature rather than by layer.

questions.question: What is code smell?
questions.answer: Symptoms in code that indicate deeper problems.

questions.question: What causes poor performance in Flutter apps?
questions.answer: Excessive rebuilds, heavy computations on UI thread, and inefficient layouts.

questions.question: What is const constructor?
questions.answer: Const constructors prevent unnecessary widget rebuilds.

questions.question: What is widget rebuild?
questions.answer: Recreating widgets when state changes.

questions.question: What is RepaintBoundary?
questions.answer: It isolates repaint areas to improve rendering performance.

questions.question: What is lazy loading?
questions.answer: Loading data or widgets only when needed.

questions.question: What is ListView.builder?
questions.answer: It builds list items lazily for better performance.

questions.question: What is Flutter DevTools?
questions.answer: A suite of performance and debugging tools.

questions.question: What is frame rendering?
questions.answer: Drawing UI frames at 60 or 120 FPS.

questions.question: What is jank?
questions.answer: Dropped frames causing stutter in UI.

questions.question: How do you optimize images?
questions.answer: By resizing, caching, and using proper formats.

questions.question: Why is testing important?
questions.answer: Testing ensures reliability, correctness, and maintainability.

questions.question: What are unit tests?
questions.answer: Tests that verify individual functions or classes.

questions.question: What are widget tests?
questions.answer: Tests that verify UI behavior in isolation.

questions.question: What are integration tests?
questions.answer: Tests that verify complete app flows.

questions.question: What is testWidgets?
questions.answer: A function used to write widget tests in Flutter.

questions.question: What is mockito?
questions.answer: A mocking framework for unit tests.

questions.question: What is bloc_test?
questions.answer: A package for testing BLoC state transitions.

questions.question: What is golden testing?
questions.answer: Testing UI appearance using image comparison.

questions.question: What is code coverage?
questions.answer: Measures how much code is exercised by tests.

questions.question: What is CI testing?
questions.answer: Running automated tests in continuous integration pipelines.

questions.question: What are platform channels?
questions.answer: They allow Flutter to communicate with native Android and iOS code.

questions.question: What is MethodChannel?
questions.answer: MethodChannel is used to invoke native methods from Flutter.

questions.question: What is EventChannel?
questions.answer: EventChannel streams data from native to Flutter.

questions.question: What is BasicMessageChannel?
questions.answer: Used for simple message passing between Flutter and native.

questions.question: How do you build APK?
questions.answer: Using flutter build apk.

questions.question: How do you build iOS app?
questions.answer: Using flutter build ios.

questions.question: What is flavor in Flutter?
questions.answer: Flavors allow multiple app configurations like dev and prod.

questions.question: What is app signing?
questions.answer: Signing verifies the app publisher identity.

questions.question: What is Play Store release?
questions.answer: Publishing the app to Google Play Store.

questions.question: What is App Store submission?
questions.answer: Publishing the app to Apple App Store.
